bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 24, 1954

div1.p: Tate states he was merely a clerk of the main hospital, but that his reporter instincts kept him looking for the story in the yellow fever experiments. He also expresses his hope that Hench will give appropriate recognition to Lazear, Ames, Lambert and Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 24, 1954
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, 3, California
February 24, 1954
P. S. HENCH, M.D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I am sending you some material relating in a small way
to the Yellow Fever Experiment. I take this liberty be-
cause of the times you have complimented me by the ex-
pressed desire to talk with me.

But, as you know my position in that experiment was not
of a doctor, nurse nor volunteer, there is nothing in that
line that I could give you first-hand.--And I'm a very
poor talker anyway.

I was merely the clerk of the main hospital.--But in that
position I met nearly all of the doctors there, all of the
nurses and all but one of the army volunteers.

As a man who had jumped from a five year service as a re-
porter on the Washington Evening Star into army uniform,
I realized more than many there what a big thing was really
going on there.

My newspaper habit kept me looking for the “story,” es-
pecially the human interest feature. So I talked to every- ✓
one I could and saw little things unnoticed by others.

From time to time I have written to others about a few of
these observations which differed from published versions.
I am enclosing some of these to you. I feel that with your
extensive research in this matter you will fine nothing
new in these papers, but they may verify some of your
findings or give you a new angle on some simple things.

In reading publications about the experiment I am aston-
ished at the little real recognition given to Lazear,
Ames, Lambert, and, even Finlay, especially the first two.

I am so anxious to see your book correct this injustice,
and I feel sure it will.--For, remarkable as it is, you
are not only a great physician and scientist, but also a
damn good reporter! You always write not of names doing
so-and-so, but of human beings--the human interest angle.

Hoping you will not think me impertinent, but am writing
only because of a deep interest in your work,
div1.closer:
Sincerely & Cordially, Paul L. Tate Paul L. Tate
Upon looking over this stuff, I think it resembles "sending
coals to Newcastle," and I am strongly tempted to toss it
into the waste-basket...But, oh well---You probably
have a better and bigger basket, so I'll leave you do the
tossing!
